review.title: Interactive Submodular Set Cover
review.abstract: We introduce a natural generalization of submodular set cover and exact active learning with a finite hypothesis class (query learning). We call this new problem interactive submodular set cover. Applications include advertising in social networks with hidden information. We give an approximation guarantee for a greedy algorithm and give a hardness of approximation result which matches up to constant factors. We also discuss the adaptivity gap for the problem and present encouraging early experimental results.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: As a motivating example, we consider viral marketing in a social network. In the standard version of the problem, the goal is to send advertising to influential members of a social network, so that by sending advertising to only a few people our message is spread to a large part of the network. Previous work [13, 12] has shown that the influence of a set of nodes can be modelled as a submodular set function. Therefore, the selection of a small set of nodes with maximum impact can be posed as a submodular functional problem. The associated problem of selecting a minimal set of nodes to achieve a desired influence is a submodular set cover problem. Both problems can be solved roughly by a greedy approach to an algorithm.

sections.text: Golovin and Krause show similar results as we do for a different but related class of problems, which also include interactive (i.e. sequential, adaptive) optimization of submodular functions. However, what Golovin and Krause call realization problems corresponds to hypotheses in our work, while items and states correspond to queries and responses. In this sense, our results are less generalizable than our results. But, in other ways, our results are more generally valid than the approximation guarantees shown by Golovin and Krause that the problem is adaptive submodality; adaptive submodality depends not only on the goal, but also on the amount of possible realizations and the probability distribution.

sections.heading: 6.3 Adaptivity Gap
sections.text: Another simple approach is to ignore feedback and solve the coverage problem for all h-H. We call this the Cover-All Method. This method is an example of a non-adaptive method: A non-adaptive (i.e. non-interactive) method is any method that does not use answers to previous questions to decide which question to ask next. The Adaptivity Gap [6] for a problem describes how much worse the best non-adaptive method can be compared to the best adaptive method. For interactive submodular coverage, we define the adaptivity gap as the maximum ratio between the cost of the optimal non-adaptive strategy and the optimal adaptive strategy. With this definition, we can show that unlike related problems [1] where the adaptivity gap is a constant, the adaptivity gap for interactive submodular coverage is quite large. Theorem 4: The adaptivity gap for modular submodular coverage is at least twice as large.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments
sections.text: We tested our method on the interactive, dominant problem described in Section 4. In this problem, we are primarily given a graph and H is a series of possibly overlapping clusters of nodes. The goal is to find a small group of nodes that simultaneously form a dominant group of initially unknown target groups h-o-H. After selecting each node, we get a feedback indicating whether the selected node in the target group (Simultaneous Learning and Covering) simultaneously forms a dominant target group h-o and finds a dominant set for it. We compare two fundamentals: a method that first identifies accurately and then finds a dominant set for the target group (Learn then Cover) and a method that simply finds a dominating set for uniting all clusters (Cover All). Note that Theorem 3 and Theorem 4 apply to the coverage of all applicable methods, so these have no theoretical guarantees.

sections.heading: 8 Future Work
sections.text: We believe that there are other interesting applications that can be used as an interactive submodular set envelope. In some applications, it may be difficult to calculate F-α accurately because H can be very large or even infinite. In these cases, it may be possible to approximate this function by scanning H. It is also important to consider methods that can deal with incorrectly stated hypotheses classes and noise within learning. One approach might be to extend agnostic active learning [2] to a similar interactive optimization environment.
